Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC at Oklahoma State University: Center for Sustainably Integrated Buildings and Sites (SIBS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mitigation of severe negative impacts on the climate will require an 80% reduction in total carbon emissions by 2050. Commercial and residential buildings are responsible for 40% of greenhouse gas emissions in developed countries. Therefore, it is not possible to achieve the required reduction in global emissions without substantive reductions from buildings. Despite this need, current buildings commonly consume significantly higher amounts of energy and emit more pollutants than predicted during the building design process. Prediction inaccuracies persist partly because engineers and archi-tects seldom receive any feedback as to actual energy performance and partly because there is a lack of deeply integrated knowledge regarding building equipment, operation and grid/environmental in-teractions in a way that a designer can utilize. The center for Sustainably Integrated Buildings and Sites (SIBS) plans to address the lack of integration and feedback with a convergence of multidisci-plinary research expertise to address inaccuracies in building energy predictions with the vision of developing a scientifically rigorous transformation to the building design process. The activities will also support an increase in scientific literacy, U.S. competitiveness, and industry collaborations by disseminating center outcomes to relevant professional societies, educating high-volumes of students in this field and construction of high-value research infrastructure.

Many next-generation buildings to not achieve optimal efficiency and minimal environmental impact as a result of a lack of feedback from the occupied building and a lack of deeply integrated knowledge between building equipment and operation that the designer can utilize. Conflating the aforementioned challenge is the omnipresent shift in regulatory environment that is currently requir-ing all equipment manufacturers to re-design their equipment to include working fluids with less en-vironmental impact. To address these challenges requires a paradigm shift in the approach to building science research that includes a deeper integration of the various disciplines and stakeholders and converges the outcomes to advance the state-of-the-art in building sciences. To support this, SIBS-OSU has a mission to develop integrated solutions within three major topical areas; (1) transition of building heating and cooling equipment to low-Global Warming Potential (GWP) refrigerants, (2) deployment of physical/cyber-physical building systems in grid and internet-connected environments (3) sustainable minimization of the environmental impact of building systems. To support the global SIBS mission, these areas will leverage the long-standing legacy in building thermal systems and equipment research to facilitate research collaborations between the building equipment manufactur-ers with the engineers and practitioners that design, build, and operate the buildings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Center for Integrated Building Systems (CIBS) at Oklahoma State University (OSU) was successfully planned as an outcome of this award and kicked-off in October of 2020. Based on industry feedback, CIBS has generated a vision to integrate building systems to maximize comfort and efficiency of buildings of the future. CIBS will do this while providing tangible outcomes and talent for our members.

The planning process included an evaluation of the needs of potential industrial partners and exploring the challenges that they face as a result of market demands and other external factors. Conversations with over 80 people at 35 different companies resulted in 5 major research thrusts that best match the needs of our potential industry partners against the skills of the faculty at OSU. These thrusts were distilled into tangible categories that the faculty utilized to brainstorm solutions with the direct support of our industry partners.

The CIBS faculty then worked directly with our industry partners to develop concrete projects which address the problems they face in each of the 5 thrust areas. These projects were presented at a planning meeting where our vision and mission was shared with members of the industrial community. The CIBS faculty (13 in total) presented 20 projects to the members and received project evaluations from the members. This meeting served as a basis for recruiting for the center.

Following the planning meeting 7 industry partners committed to membership and the center kicked-off in October of 2020 and selected its first projects that will start in 2021. There were 11 CIBS faculty that pitched over 20 ideas to the CIBS Industrial Advisory Board based on the 5 research thrusts, which resulted in 4 projects selected for CIBS inaugural year in 2021.

CIBS shows great potential to make an impact for our membership by providing the intellectual impact required to design the next generation of integrated building systems. Additionally, CIBS will provide the institutional infrastructure to support the development of under-represented groups and the building community, at-large.
